title: Was the NFC North the most cursed conference in the 2022 season?
text:
NFC North fans have been let down time after time watching their team throughout the entire 2022 season. The NFC North consists of the Green Bay Packers, Detroit Lions, Chicago Bears, and Minnesota Vikings. These teams had high hopes for 2022; however, they continuously finish in an unwanted standing.
The last time a team in the NFC North played in the Super Bowl was in 2011 with Green Bay winning. The conference ranks among the last in the league for Super Bowl appearances. In fact, the Lions have never even won a NFC North title. The last time they won a title was in 1993, when the conference was the NFC Central.
The NFC North has been consistent on offense, but their defense have been questionable. Fans could see a different dynamic between the conference throughout the entire 2022 season, for better and for worse.
This begs the question: Was the NFC North the most cursed conference in the 2022 season?
Let’s take a look at the numbers.
To start, the chart will showcase the total takeaways for each NFL team throughout the season. The more takeaways, the better. Where do the NFC North defenses rank among the rest of the league?


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggalt)
library(waffle)
library(ggrepel)

nfl <- read_csv("defense.csv")

turnovers <- nfl |>
  group_by(Team) |>
  summarise(
    Giveaways = sum(OffInt,Fum),
    Takeaways = sum(TO))

gb <- turnovers |>
  filter(Team == "Green Bay Packers")

mn <- turnovers |>
  filter(Team == "Minnesota Vikings")

ch <- turnovers |>
  filter(Team == "Chicago Bears")

dt <- turnovers |>
  filter(Team == "Detroit Lions")

ggplot() +
  geom_lollipop(
    data=turnovers,
    aes(y=reorder(Team, Takeaways), x=Takeaways),
    horizontal = TRUE
    ) +
  geom_lollipop(
    data=gb,
    aes(y=Team, x=Takeaways),
    horizontal = TRUE,
    color = "darkgreen"
  ) +
  geom_lollipop(
    data=dt,
    aes(y=Team, x=Takeaways),
    horizontal = TRUE,
    color = "lightblue"
  ) +
  geom_lollipop(
    data=mn,
    aes(y=Team, x=Takeaways),
    horizontal = TRUE,
    color = "purple"
  ) +
  geom_lollipop(
    data=ch,
    aes(y=reorder(Team, Takeaways), x=Takeaways),
    horizontal = TRUE,
    color = "orange"
  ) +
  theme_light() +
  labs(
    title = "The NFC North's 2022 Defense: Middle of the Pack",
    subtitle = "Vikings owned the conference with the best defense.",
    caption = "Source: Pro Football Reference | By: Lauren Aleknavicius ",
    y= ""
  ) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face ="bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )





Now, let’s look at how the offense compares in rushing and passing yards. The Lions, surprisingly, finished 5th in the league. Thus, the Lions were at the top compared to the rest of the NFC North in total yards. The Vikings were closest in competition to the Lions finishing 7th overall.
So, is the NFC North actually a force to be reckoned with on offense? Meaning, does this conference have the worst luck in history?


Code
yds <- read_csv("offense.csv")

north <- yds |>
  select(
    Team, Conf, PassYds, RushYds
  ) |>
  filter(Conf == "NFC North")

dtwaffle <- c("Rushing"=2179, "Passing"=4281)
chwaffle <- c("Rushing"=3014, "Passing"=2219, 1227)
gbwaffle <- c("Rushing"=2113, "Passing"=3632, 715)
mnwaffle <- c("Rushing"=1661, "Passing"=4484, 315)
iron(
waffle(
  dtwaffle/20,
  rows=10,
  xlab= "1 square = 20 yards",
  colors = c("lightgrey", "lightblue")
) +
  labs(
    title = "Do Not Underestimate the 2022
    NFC North Offenses",
    subtitle = "Lions finish 5th in the league in total yards."
  ) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 14, face ="bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12)
  ) + 
  guides(fill=guide_legend(title="Detroit Lions")),

waffle(
  mnwaffle/20,
  rows=10,
  xlab= "1 square = 20 yards",
  colors = c("yellow", "purple", "white")
  ) + 
  guides(fill=guide_legend(title="Minnesota Vikings")),

waffle(
  mnwaffle/20,
  rows=10,
  xlab= "1 square = 20 yards",
  colors = c("darkgreen", "yellow", "white")
) + 
  guides(fill=guide_legend(title="Green Bay Packers")),

waffle (
 chwaffle/20,
  rows = 10, 
  xlab= "1 square = 20 yards",
  colors = c("orange", "navy", "white")
) +
  labs(
    caption = "Source: Pro Football Reference | By: Lauren Aleknavicius"
  ) + 
  guides(fill=guide_legend(title="Chicago Bears"))
) +
  theme(
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )





Last, we will look at the total points scored versus allowed by each team in the conference compared to the rest of the league. The Bears are ultimately the worst team on defense. They allowed the most points scored. On the other hand, the rest of the defense made stops.
Again, the Lions ranked among the highest in points scored; however, they also have some of the most points allowed. Is this why they have never won a NFC North title?


Code
totals <- read_csv("games.csv")

gbtd <- totals |>
  filter(Team == "Green Bay Packers")

mntd <- totals |>
  filter(Team == "Minnesota Vikings")

chtd <- totals |>
  filter(Team == "Chicago Bears")

dttd <- totals |>
  filter(Team == "Detroit Lions")

ggplot() +
  geom_point(
    data=totals,
    aes(x=PF, y=PA)) +
  geom_point(data=dttd, aes(x=PF, y=PA), color="lightblue", ) +
  geom_point(data=chtd, aes(x=PF, y=PA), color="orange")  +
  geom_point(data=gbtd, aes(x=PF, y=PA), color="darkgreen") +
  geom_point(data=mntd, aes(x=PF, y=PA), color="purple") + 
  geom_text_repel(data=dttd, aes(x=PF, y=PA, label="Detriot Lions"), size=3) +
  geom_text_repel(data=chtd, aes(x=PF, y=PA, label="Chicago Bears"), size=3) +
  geom_text_repel(data=gbtd, aes(x=PF, y=PA, label="Green Bay Packers"), size=3) +
  geom_text_repel(data=mntd, aes(x=PF, y=PA, label="Minnesota Vikings"), size=3) +
  labs(
    title = "2022 NFC North: Offense vs Defense Scoring",
    subtitle = "Bears ranked first with the most points allowed.",
    caption = "Source: Pro Football Reference | By: Lauren Aleknavicius ",
    x= "Points Scored",
    y= "Points Allowed"
  ) +
  theme_light() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face ="bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )





Overall, every NFC North team played surprisingly well, but just does not compare to the other teams in the league. This confirms that the conference was the most cursed throughout 2022. There is high hopes for the 2023 season.
The NFC North has had a drastic change within quarterbacks in 2023; therefore, will the teams outperform compared to last year or will they finish even worse? This question is keeping fans on their toes.
Where does the conference finish this year? Will the Lions continue to lead the conference and win their first NFC North title? Signs are pointing in their direction.

title: Hello
text: Hello- welcome to my blog! This will be where I showcase the projects I have created in SPMC350: Sports Data Analysis and Visualization. I have enjoyed learning about different tools in RStudio. I am eager to present my work with you all.

title: About
text:
Hi. My name is Lauren. I am a junior from Green Bay, Wisconsin at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. I am a double major in sports media and communications and advertising and public relations. Additionally, I am obtaining a minor in communication studies. Throughout my time in the College of Journalism and Mass Communications, I have acquired skills in time-management, communication, and more importantly team-work.
In addition to my academics, I am involved with athletics on campus that has led to various leadership positions with a plethora of individuals. I attend each practice and competition with the women’s gymnastics team as their student manager. I love being able to get in the gym everyday, while working with some of the best athletes and coaches in the NCAA. Although I have a love for gymnastics, my ultimate goal is to work in the National Football League. Football has been in my life from a young age. Being from Green Bay, I have grown up around football and I cannot wait to be in a workplace where football is the main focus.
I will be graduating early in December of 2024; therefore, I am eager to get my foot in the door within the sports industry. I am looking to bring my passion for sports, relationship building, and learning into a workplace that has exponential room for growth.
This blog will showcase my project in SPMC350: Sports Data Analysis and Visualization. Throughout the course, I have learned so much about RStudio. I look forward to presenting my findings in this blog.

title: Are the Kansas City Chiefs on track to win another Super Bowl in 2024?
text:
The Kansas City Chiefs have appeared in three of the last four Super Bowls. They came away as champions in 2020 and 2023. Although the 2023-2024 regular season is not yet complete, teams are nearing the end of their games. The data is complete through week 12 this season. Currently, the Chiefs are 8-3. This makes them first in their division, the AFC West. The other leaders in the AFC are the Miami Dolphins, Baltimore Ravens, and Jacksonville Jaguars.
Thus, are the Kansas City Chiefs on track to win another Super Bowl in 2024?
The Chiefs are hoping to continue their success into the post season. Unless something drastic happens within the league, the Chiefs will be making their eighth consecutive post season appearance. Much of their success can be contributed to the defense this season. How does the Chiefs defense compare to the other top teams in the AFC?
The Chiefs defense has been keeping the Chiefs on top; however, when comparing rushing and passing yards to the other top teams in the AFC the Chiefs are just average. As of week 12, they were first at stopping passing yards, but last in allowing the most rushing yards.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)
library(ggrepel)

afc <- read_csv("defense.csv")

afc |>
  select(
    Team, YdsPass, YdsRush
  ) |> 
  pivot_longer(
  cols=starts_with("Yds"),
  names_to="Type",
  values_to="Yards") -> afcwide 

ggplot()+
  geom_bar(
    data=afcwide,
    aes(x=reorder(Team, Yards),
        weight=Yards, fill= Type)) +
  scale_fill_manual(values=c("orangered1", "orange2")) + 
  coord_flip() +
  
    labs(
    title = "Chiefs Dominate Defensively, Rank 3rd Overall in Yards Per Play.",
    subtitle = "The Jaguars are out for revenge allowing less than 1,000 rushing yards by week 12.",
    caption = "Source: Pro Football Reference | By: Lauren Aleknavicius",
    y= "Defensive Yards Per Play",
    x=""
  ) +
  theme_light() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face ="bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )





The Chiefs offense has been yet to have solid starting game. They have been seeming to pick up speed later this season. Patrick Mahomes has started every game this season at quarterback, unlike the previous season due to an injury. Mahomes is considered one of the best quarterbacks in the league.
Although the AFC West is relatively good at passing this season, there are several teams in the hunt that are not. The Cincinnati Bengals, Tampa Bay Buccaneers, Philadelphia Eagles, and San Francisco 49ers have all appeared in the Super Bowl within the past four seasons. Each team has been a force to be reckon with. On the other hand, The New York Jets and Cleveland Browns have been consistently the worst on offense. Let’s look at passing completion by various teams.
Completed passes and total pass attempts compile together to create a completion percentage. How do the Chiefs compare to the other leaders in the AFC and previous Super Bowl contenders?


Code
passing <- read_csv("offensepass.csv")

nfloff <- c("Kansas City Chiefs", "Miami Dolphins", "Baltimore Ravens", "Jacksonville Jaguars", "Philadelphia Eagles", "Los Angeles Rams", "Cincinnati Bengals", "Tampa Bay Buccaneers", "San Francisco 49ers", "New York Jets", "Cleveland Browns")

offpass <- passing |>
  select(
    Team, Cmp, Att, CmpPct
  ) |>
  filter(Team %in% nfloff)

offpass |>
  gt() |>
  cols_label(
    Cmp = "Completed",
    Att = "Attempted",
    CmpPct = "Completion Percentage"
  ) |>

   tab_header(
    title = "AFC West Dominance Shines: Teams Lead the League.",
    subtitle = "Compared to previous Super Bowl contenders, the Chiefs rank fourth."
  ) |>
  tab_source_note( source_note = md("**By:** Lauren Aleknavicius | **Source:** Pro Football Reference")
    ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"), locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
    tab_style(
        locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
        style = list(
          cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
          cell_text(weight = "bold", size=12)
        )
      ) |>
      opt_row_striping() |>
      opt_table_lines("none") |>
   tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "red"),
      cell_text(color = "gold")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "Kansas City Chiefs")
  ) |>
   tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#241773"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "Baltimore Ravens")
  ) |>
   tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "cyan4"),
      cell_text(color = "orange")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "Miami Dolphins")
  ) |>
   tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "gold"),
      cell_text(color = "#006778")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "Jacksonville Jaguars")
  )






  
    
      AFC West Dominance Shines: Teams Lead the League.
    
    
      Compared to previous Super Bowl contenders, the Chiefs rank fourth.
    
    
      Team
      Completed
      Attempted
      Completion Percentage
    
  
  
    Miami Dolphins
265
380
69.7
    Kansas City Chiefs
283
417
67.9
    San Francisco 49ers
216
309
69.9
    Jacksonville Jaguars
254
377
67.4
    Philadelphia Eagles
242
358
67.6
    Los Angeles Rams
226
380
59.5
    Baltimore Ravens
233
342
68.1
    Tampa Bay Buccaneers
246
382
64.4
    Cincinnati Bengals
271

66.7
    Cleveland Browns
217
391
55.5
    New York Jets
225
376
59.8
  
  
    
      By: Lauren Aleknavicius | Source: Pro Football Reference
    
  
  




All four of the AFC West teams are dominating on offensive and defensive yards per play.
The Jaguars are furthest behind the rest of the pack; however, they are still no where near the worst in the league. With a powerhouse of an offensive and an indestructible defense the Kansas City Chiefs are playing at the top of the league.


Code
YPP <- read_csv ("ypp.csv")

kcypp <- YPP |>
  filter(Team == "Kansas City Chiefs")

jjypp <- YPP |>
  filter(Team == "Jacksonville Jaguars")

brypp <- YPP |>
  filter(Team == "Baltimore Ravens")

mdypp <- YPP |>
  filter(Team == "Miami Dolphins")

ggplot() +
  geom_point(
    data=YPP, aes(x=OffYPP, y=DefYPP)
  ) +
 geom_point(data=kcypp, aes(x=OffYPP, y=DefYPP), color="red", ) +
  geom_point(data=jjypp, aes(x=OffYPP, y=DefYPP), color="#006778")  +
  geom_point(data=brypp, aes(x=OffYPP, y=DefYPP), color="#241773") +
  geom_point(data=mdypp, aes(x=OffYPP, y=DefYPP), color="orange") + 
  geom_text_repel(data=kcypp, aes(x=OffYPP, y=DefYPP, label="Kansas City Chiefs"), size=3.5) +
  geom_text_repel(data=jjypp, aes(x=OffYPP, y=DefYPP, label="Jacksonville Jaguars"), size=3.5) +
  geom_text_repel(data=brypp, aes(x=OffYPP, y=DefYPP, label="Baltimore Ravens"), size=3.5) +
  geom_text_repel(data=mdypp, aes(x=OffYPP, y=DefYPP, label="Miami Dolphins"), size=3.5) +
  labs(
    title = "AFC West Dominance Shines: Teams Lead the League.",
    subtitle = "The Dolphins lead the AFC in offensive yards per play, but the Chiefs are just average.",
    caption = "Source: Pro Football Reference | By: Lauren Aleknavicius ",
    x= "Offensive Yards Per Play",
    y= "Defensive Yards Per Play"
  ) +
  theme_light() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face ="bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )





Overall, the Kansas City Chiefs are on pace to win another Lombardi Trophy. Their offense is once again unstoppable, but something is different this year. The Chiefs defense is finally stepping up to the plate. With such dominate defense, the Chiefs are in a great position for playing in their second straight Super Bowl.
The Kansas City Chiefs will be a force to be reckon with in the post season in hopes of making another Super Bowl appearance in 2024.
